head.title: ‘Searching for My Lady’s Bonnet: discovering poetry in the National Library of Australia’s newspapers database’ | Digital Scholarship in the Humanities | Oxford Academic

div.h1: ‘Searching for My Lady’s Bonnet: discovering poetry in the National Library of Australia’s newspapers database’

div.div: The School of Communication and Arts, The University of Queensland, Australia

Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_1, April 2017, Pages i69–i83, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqw062

div.p: Kerry Kilner, Kent Fitch, ‘Searching for My Lady’s Bonnet: discovering poetry in the National Library of Australia’s newspapers database’, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_1, April 2017, Pages i69–i83, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqw062

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: AustLit is a major Australian cultural heritage database and the most comprehensive record of a nation’s literary history in the world. In this article we will present the successful results of a project addressing the challenge of discovering and recording creative writing published in digitized historical Australian newspapers, provided by the National Library of Australia’s Trove service. As a first step in identifying creative writing, we developed an automated method for identifying articles that are likely to be poems by searching for a number of signals embedded in articles. When this work began, AustLit contained more than 10,200 bibliographical records for poems published between 1803 and 1954 (75% prior to 1900) with links to the full text in 115 different newspapers. The aim of the project was to expand this number of bibliographical records in AustLit and provide a foundation for analysing the importance of poetry in newspaper publishing of the period. Taking advantage of Ted Underwood’s (Getting Everything you Want from HathiTrust http://tedunderwood.com/2012/07/27/getting-everything-you-want-from-hathitrust/, and Open Data (http://tedunderwood.com/open-data/): The Stone and the Shell, Underwood blog posts (Both accessed 27 October 2015), 2012) work with seventeenth- and eighteenth-century full text in the HathiTrust collection, we trained a naive Bayesian classifier, modifying code from Daniel Shiffman (Bayesian Filtering. http://shiffman.net/teaching/a2z_2008/bayesian/ (accessed 27 October 2015), 2008) and Paul Graham (A Plan for Spam. http://www.paulgraham.com/spam.html (accessed 27 October 2015), 2002) and improving the quality of Optical Character Recognition (OCR) by using the overProof correction algorithm. We have been able to successfully identify large numbers of poems in the newspapers database, greatly expanding AustLit’s coverage of this important literary form. After suitable training of the classifier, we were able to successfully identify 88% of the newspaper articles that a knowledgeable human would classify as ‘poetry’. Our results have encouraged us to consider enhancing and extending the techniques to aid the identification of other forms of literature and criticism.

blockquote.p: To you all readers turn, and then can look
Pleased on your pages, who abhor a book;
Those who ne’er deign their Bible to peruse,
Await expectant the Sabbath morning’s news… (Walker, 1976)

div.p: The AustLit database (Kilner, 2002) contains bibliographical records for more than 882,000 works of Australian creative and critical writing and over 161,000 author and organization records. As an information resource, it is unsurpassed in comprehensiveness and breadth of coverage and is a central plank in Australia’s research infrastructure for the fields of cultural history and heritage. As a full-text repository, AustLit contains over a thousand items selected and digitized from original documents. These comprise seminal works of nineteenth and early twentieth-century Australian literature, a collection of early speculative fiction, a large corpus of early children’s literature, and selected criticism and scholarly works. Much of the creative writing full text is out of copyright, and we are soon to embark upon a digitization project to make available play-scripts written and performed in the first half of the twentieth century. In addition to this aspect of our activities, AustLit’s comprehensive bibliographical records link outwards to more than 80,000 full-text items that are available online. This selection, curation, and development of full-text collections make AustLit a valuable site for finding contextualized reading material and content that supports historical research and teaching.

Despite providing the most comprehensive record of Australian literary history available, there remain areas in which our coverage is lacking; most particularly in the area of works published in periodicals. Like many researchers working in Australian cultural history, the National Library of Australia’s (NLA) newspapers database, available through Trove, provides new opportunities for understanding our cultural heritage. Trove is an important element in our plans for expanding AustLit’s bibliographical record and our contextualized full-text delivery. The digitized newspapers offer an opportunity to build our corpus of records and deliver access to more full text, to advance knowledge about the place of literature in society, and to provide insights into the reading practices across the period from the early nineteenth to the mid-twentieth centuries. Newspapers were frequently the primary form of transmission for Australian literature, especially poetry, during the period covered by the NLA’s database. The possibility of identifying and unlocking the literary content allows AustLit to support new research into reading culture and to make our bibliographical record more comprehensive and reflective of the place of literature in society. In her work on Australian literature published in country newspapers in the 1840s, Elizabeth Webby says:
For poets in particular, newspapers and magazines offered about the only form of publication since British publishers were not interested in Australian poetry and book publication in Australia could only be achieved at the author’s expense or by subscription. […] In nearly all cases, though of considerable literary and historical interest, this material is still ‘blushing unseen’ in the dusty pages or microfilm reels of the papers concerned. (Webby, 2000)

Trove’s newspapers database now allows those poems and other literary material to ‘blush’ in the full light of day. However, it remains a challenge to find the poetry within the morass of newspaper print as Trove does not identify the genre or form of newspaper items, collecting most content under the simple descriptor of ‘article’. Researchers need to know what they are looking for to use Trove effectively. They are unable to search for all poetry in a particular newspaper, for example, though they are able to search for particular keywords that appear in poetry to expose individual poems.

In this article we will present the results of a project attempting to address the challenge of discovering creative writing published in Australian newspapers by developing an automated method for identifying articles that are likely to be poems. Success in identifying the publication of creative writing in Australian newspapers is, we hope, the first step in harvesting the actual full text from the newspapers and expanding the corpus of Australian literature available through AustLit, thereby enabling the use of data, and other forms of digital, analytics.

We began with poetry because the physical features of this form of creative writing—the shape of verse on the page, the frequent use of rhyming and poetic words—make it possible to locate works that are not explicitly identified as poetry in other ways. In 2014 Bode and Hetherington undertook exploratory indexing work on fiction published in Australian newspapers. They identify the immense scale of the work required and the impossibility of manually identifying works of interest as the motivation for using digital methods of discovery. Their work, which is based on searching for serialized fiction, used the Trove API to identify articles matching their keyword search terms to scrape the bibliographic metadata of matching items from the database. This was followed by manual checking to create the beginnings of an index. The scale of this work remains enormous and is unlikely to be completely successful without deploying algorithmic solutions.

The volume of poetry published in the newspapers delivered through Trove is likely to be vastly greater than serialized novels or other forms of literature. In his history of NSW newspapers, R. B. Walker notes that ‘versifying was a common accomplishment and almost every journal had its poets’ corner’ (Walker, 1976). Poetry has its uses, its proponents, and its critics. In the newspapers, throughout the nineteenth and early twentieth century, it appears as political satire or commentary, as poems in praise of the bush and the ‘new’ world of Australia, love poems, humorous ditties on local affairs, in Memoria, as serious reflections on life and the world, and in many forms from sonnets to odes and long-form narrative poems. Not all editors appreciated the popular place poetry held in the hearts of nineteenth-century readers who obviously saw the newspapers as a forum for their own verse. The acerbic editor of the Hunter River Gazette wrote to his readers in 1842:
We have, at present, a great deal of Poetry in our possession dated from every part of the district, and of varying degrees of merit; but none of it possessing the impress of that sublimity which is necessary to secure for it admission into our columns. The time and trouble expended by a certain portion of the community in the composition of what our poetical friends are pleased to call Poetry, is really inconceivable, and we seriously intend to call the attention of the public to the great amount of energy thus idly wasted, and which might be applied to some more useful pursuit. … Anyone possessed of a tolerable ear, may perpetrate the sin of rhyme, but let him not in God’s name offend us by calling it Poetry.

Whether poetry was used as a filler to ensure no column wastage or as a genuine engagement with an emerging literary scene, it was presented to newspaper readers on a daily basis. Although AustLit has expended considerable effort in indexing the literary content of newspapers across Australia’s print culture history over many years, at the point of embarking on this project, we were aware that AustLit has no more than skimmed the surface of an enormous quantity of poetry published in newspapers.

The project began in July 2014. At that time AustLit contained more than 10,200 links to poems identified within the NLA’s Digitised Newspapers collection. These poems were published between 1803 and 1954 (75% prior to 1900) and across 115 different titles. The major contributing titles were Australian Town and Country Journal (2,803 articles) and The Queenslander (1,717 articles). Each of the links in the AustLit records had been manually created by a combination of inspired searching for words from a known poem, or for works by a specific author, or for known literary columns, and by systematic browsing through each page of each issue of nominated newspaper titles across specific date ranges. As a scholarly bibliography, we aim to provide an accurate and (eventually) comprehensive record of the history of Australian literature. Finding out how extensive the presence of poetry was in historical newspapers remains an enticing problem for us. Bibliographies of Australian poetry have largely been limited to recording the publication of book length works, often covering specific periods or geographical regions.1 Scholar of nineteenth-century Australian literary culture, Elizabeth Webby, laboriously compiled a bibliography of original poetry published before 1850 in newspapers, magazines, and almanacs (Webby, 1982). But given the major increase in newspaper publication following 1850, there remain major gaps in knowledge.

One of AustLit’s recent research projects was the Colonial Newspapers and Magazines Project (CNMP), undertaken by researchers at the University of NSW, Canberra. This project attempted to create a literary ‘map’ of Australia’s colonial period by collecting and recording information about the reading habits of Australians before 1900 and inserting these findings into AustLit’s data structures. This huge task took a horizontal approach to indexing literary content by concentrating on 3 specific years in the 1800s (1838, 1868, and 1888) representative of 50 and 100 years after the arrival of the First Fleet of colonists, and a mid-point—1868—in the colonial era. Whilst producing accurate and near-complete results, the only feasible method of browsing every page of selected titles is extremely labour intensive. During the 2 years of focused attention on this project, the researchers (1.4 equivalent full-time librarians) created almost 60,000 work records in AustLit ranging across creative writing, reviews, correspondence, and advertisements that related to the book trade, printers and printing, the literary arts, and relevant cultural activities.2

This data set of colonial-era bibliographical records exposed a vein of the literature published in the newspapers and was one of the inspirations for us to investigate automated approaches to identifying relevant content beyond the parameters of the CNMP. The announcement by the HathiTrust Research Centre in June 20143 of the alpha release of a new data set, consisting of page-level features extracted from a quarter of a million text volumes, was the impetus for our project, as it seemed a proof of concept for what we needed to do to expand our coverage of literature published in newspapers.

As a starting point, we noted the effectiveness of Ted Underwood’s genre identification approaches on seventeenth- and eighteenth-century texts digitized by the HathiTrust (Underwood, 2012). We extracted data from Underwood’s eighteenth- and nineteenth-century ‘Joint’ and ‘Verse Only’ corpora to produce two vocabulary frequency lists: one of all words and one of words found in works of poetry.

We used these data to train a naive Bayesian classifier, modifying code from Daniel Shiffman (2008), which itself was a variation on an approach to spam devised by Paul Graham (2002). The Bayesian classifier must first be trained by presenting it with occurrences of words from content already classified (by a human) as poetry and with occurrences of words from content not classified. The classifier hence calculates the likelihood that an instance of a word has been observed as being present in a poem. Words such as ‘love’, ‘swoon’, and ‘devotion’ are much more likely to appear in poetry than ‘arrears’, ‘bookkeeper’, and ‘dysentery’. Words such as ‘horse’, ‘duty’, and ‘time’ are less discriminating. Words from articles which may be poems are then presented to the classifier, and the 15 most discriminating words are examined to construct a score representing the probability (as computed by the classifier) that the article is poetry (refer to Graham for a detailed discussion; just substitute the use of the word ‘poem’ for his use of the word ‘spam’).

The discriminating ability of the Bayesian classifier is dependent on the size of the training data (the more the better, but with diminishing returns) and how representative the training data are of the content to be classified. That is, the poetic and non-poetic vocabulary distribution of the training data should be close to that of the content to be classified.

We then ran the trained classifier on two sets of OCRed text of newspaper articles. The first set consisted of 10,252 articles identified as poetry in AustLit which were linked to a specific article in the NLA’s Digitised Newspaper corpus. Although some of these poems had been identified by the selective indexing of the CNMP project, many more had been linked from AustLit in the years since the NLA Digitised Newspapers became available in 2008, and hence they represent content from many years and newspaper titles that spanned the country. The second set consisted of 2,576 articles selected from the NLA Digitised Newspaper corpus whose article id number ended in ‘33333’ or ‘55555’, that is, effectively ‘random’.

The poetry classification procedure uses the current text available in NLA newspapers. Almost always this is the raw (original) OCR text. Some articles may have been partially or completely corrected by a human, in which case we use that corrected text. As a separate test, the text of the articles we were trying to classify was passed through overProof (see below), so see what difference better text made to the classification process.

The initial results were disappointing: using the Bayesian classifier as the sole arbiter of ‘poetry’ produced a low positive poetry classification of known poetry items (under 70%), and reducing the classifier’s threshold to classify more as ‘poetry’ produced a very large number of ‘false positives’ in the unknown set.

These results seemed to suggest that our training data, Ted Underwood’s ‘Joint’ and ‘Verse Only’ corpora, may not contain text sufficiently representative of Australian newspaper content, or that the algorithm which works so well for spam may need to be tuned to work reliably for a possibly more subtle task of distinguishing poetry from prose. One major reason for the poor discriminating ability of the Bayesian classifier was obvious: many articles contained only a small amount of poetry amidst much text (Fig. 4).

Hence, we decided to investigate using additional ‘signals’ to increase classification accuracy. Examination of classification failures (both false negatives largely from the first set of known-poetry articles and false positives from the second set of unclassified articles) led to augmenting our classification heuristics using the following signals:

Left indent variation. Poetry seemed to have more consecutive lines with differing left indent than other content. We calculated the average difference of the left offset of each pair of consecutive lines in the article being examined.

Line length variation. Poetry seemed to have greater variation in length of consecutive lines. We calculated the average difference in the number of characters (including punctuation and inter-word spaces) of each pair of consecutive lines in the article being examined. However, we noted many systematic contra-indications from placing too much weight on both the left indent and line length signals: country show competition and sporting results, legal lists, and timetables are frequently formatted as indented lists, lists of jokes, and commentary on who-was-wearing-what at social gatherings are frequently formatted as very short paragraphs (two to three lines) exhibiting indent and line length variations (Fig. 1).

img.alt: Examples of non-poetic articles with significant left indent and/or line length variation. Stable URLS

div.p: Examples of non-poetic articles with significant left indent and/or line length variation. Stable URLS

img.alt: Examples of non-poetic articles with significant left indent and/or line length variation. Stable URLS

div.p: Examples of non-poetic articles with significant left indent and/or line length variation. Stable URLS

Rhyming lines. Poetry can be expected to have more lines which rhyme with previous lines than non-poetry. We tried several approaches to detecting rhymes, starting with the very simple assumption that lines ending with the same two characters rhymed, before evaluating two approaches based on different algorithms and rhyming dictionaries, the second of which was based on the Carnegie Mellon University (CMU) pronunciation dictionary and proved reasonably effective. We first found it necessary to exclude common words from contention as rhymes because of their frequency of repetition (e.g. ‘the’ and ‘and’), but we then excluded ‘same word’ rhymes. However, we still found it beneficial to exclude weekdays (‘Monday’, ‘Tuesday’, etc.) to reduce rhyme matches on timetables and other lists. We also found that special handling of hyphens (treating them as a space) and ignoring one character words at the end of a line (which were often OCR artefacts) improved rhyme detection. The rhyming dictionary did not include some common words starting with ‘un’ or ‘de’ (such as ‘unassisted’ or ‘de-enlist’), so for reasonably long words with an ‘un’ or ‘de’ prefix, if no entry was found in the rhyming dictionary, we tried the unprefixed version. A large number of words we encountered in known-poetry articles were not in the dictionary, such as ‘windless’ (which hence did not rhyme with ‘endless’), ‘outspread’ (with ‘dead’), ‘lonesomeness’ (with ‘wilderness’), ‘crag’ (with ‘drag’), and ‘tinting’ (with ‘glinting’). The CMU rhyming dictionary is based on North American spelling and pronunciations, which meant some rhymes based on ‘Australian’ or British spellings and pronunciations were not found. For example, ‘colouring’ (with ‘king’) and ‘wool’ (with ‘fool’) were not found to rhyme, the latter pair because the rhyming dictionary has the ‘oo’ in wool as sounding like ‘uw’, but the ‘oo’ in ‘fool’ sounding like ‘uh’. As well, frequent poetic ‘constructs’ such as ‘aye'll’ and ‘O're’ do not appear in the rhyming dictionary (see for example, the vocabulary of this poem: http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71020816) (Fig. 2).

img.alt: Unusual rhyming words that confounded the CMU Rhyming Dictionary

div.p: Unusual rhyming words that confounded the CMU Rhyming Dictionary

img.alt: Unusual rhyming words that confounded the CMU Rhyming Dictionary

div.p: Unusual rhyming words that confounded the CMU Rhyming Dictionary
Furthermore, word pairs that humans would accept as rhymes with a bit of a squint, such as ‘mould/soul’, ‘pane/name’, ‘so/shows’ were rejected by the dictionary-based rhyming algorithm.

The rhyme detection algorithm seemed to yield most discriminating contributions to classification heuristics when looking up to three lines back for a rhyming match: looking more lines back started to find too many rhymes by chance in non-poetry. However, some poems have formatting and line breaks imposed by their publication in newspapers which means one line of poetry is split over two typeset lines, for example, the unattributed, ‘The Model Church’: http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70613007 (Fig. 3).
Complex rhyming schemes
Complex rhyming schemes

img.alt: The problem of poor zoning of poetry resulting in non-identification

div.p: The problem of poor zoning of poetry resulting in non-identification

img.alt: The problem of poor zoning of poetry resulting in non-identification

div.p: The problem of poor zoning of poetry resulting in non-identification
Apart from blank verse not being identified, some poems have more complex rhyming schemes than our algorithm could detect: basically, a rhyme based on the final syllable in the final word on a line.

Finally, rhyme detection was particularly susceptible to OCR errors (Fig. 5). We noted that the OCR errors appear to be higher at starts and ends of lines. This is often due to skewing at the edges of a page or the misidentification of a column boundary as a letter, and appending to final word on a line the letter I, the numeral 1, or the bar character (|). The examples below, of the OCRed text taken from noisy newspaper pages, show the original (uncorrected) text of articles, in which the algorithm failed to detect rhymes despite them being obvious to a human. They were, however, still classified as poetry due to other signals, after the very poor OCRed text was automatically corrected with the overProof software. This demonstrates the additional complexity of identifying poetic text and the further steps that need to be taken to increase recognition:

img.alt: An example of poor OCR making it impossible to recognize rhyming or poetic structure

div.p: An example of poor OCR making it impossible to recognize rhyming or poetic structure

img.alt: An example of poor OCR making it impossible to recognize rhyming or poetic structure

div.p: An example of poor OCR making it impossible to recognize rhyming or poetic structure

From the AustLit set of 10,252 known-poetry articles, 411 had no rhymes detected at all after applying automatic OCR correction with overProof. Of these 411, 269 were still classified as poetry based on one and/or another of the following signals.
Presence of digits in OCRed text. Digits are less common in poetry than other articles, particularly some forms of lists such as timetables, stock market reports, sporting scoreboards, and judicial lists which otherwise score highly on line length and left indent variation.
Presence of ‘positive’ words (such as ‘poem’, ‘poetry’, ‘poetic’, ‘poet’, and ‘verse’) and ‘negative’ words and phrases (such as ‘shipping news’, ‘forecast’, ‘to the editor’, ‘today’s shows’, ‘government’, ‘council’, ‘market’, and ‘advertising’) in the first few lines of the article.
Article tags. The public are free to assign tags to articles in the NLA newspapers corpus. We considered a tag value of ‘poetry’ or ‘poem’ as a very strong evidence for an article to be classified as poetry.
Article classification. Articles classified by the digitization contractor as ‘Family notices’ or ‘Advertising’ were less likely to contain material AustLit staff would want to classify as poetry.

After applying these signals, our initial results correctly classified as poetry just over 80% of articles associated with AustLit poetry records by a link to the newspapers database (Fig. 6). Manual examination of the articles not identified (the false negatives) revealed that the vast majority were articles containing a small amount of poetry set within a sea of prose. A significant other group was written using a vocabulary not typical of poetry (words such as ‘proclamation’, ‘neutrality’, and ‘precautions’ which pushed the classifier towards rejection as poetry), and there was another large group of articles with such poor OCR that few words were accurately identified. AustLit indexing practices do not allow time for the correction of the articles to which our records are linked. If we had been able to correct the text as we indexed the newspaper content, our hit rate would have been higher. A single error in AustLit linking to the incorrect article was also identified.
overProof software demonstrating improved OCR
overProof software demonstrating improved OCR

Refinement of the rhyming detection algorithm and incremental improvements at combining the weights of the above signals resulted in 83.9% of articles from the ‘known’ set of 10,252 articles being classified as poetry. A random sample of 45 articles which our algorithm failed to identify as poetry was examined. Of these, about 60% were articles of which only a small part was poetry, about 15% were poems containing vocabulary unusual for a poem, in another 15% the OCRed ‘vocabulary’ of the article was so poor as to be significantly or largely gibberish, and in the remainder were a combination of these and other causes such as little or no rhyming and unusual (i.e. ‘regular’) layout.
By far the biggest cause of non-identification was a poem appearing in the midst of a much longer article, the contents of which were overwhelmingly not poetic.

Sometimes this was caused by poor article zoning (in which the poem has been erroneously included as part of a separate article, but mostly it occurs because the poem is just a small part of the article’s contents (for example).

We experimented with trying to detect runs of poetry in a ‘rolling window’ of 12 consecutive lines. However, in long articles, this yielded far more ‘false positives’ (from a 12-line section having more rhymes than average and/or a slightly ‘poetic’ vocabulary and/or multiple small paragraphs generating high line length and indent scores) than ‘true positives’. (‘False positives’ are those articles incorrectly classified as poetry, ‘false negatives’ are those articles which should have been identified as poetry, but were not.) Developing better heuristics for identifying islands of genuine poetry in a sea of prose is an area of further work.
http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14495530 http://overproof.projectcomputing.com/showRequest/1404720163070639
http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14495530 http://overproof.projectcomputing.com/showRequest/1404720163070639

View Large

Another significant cause of misclassification was poor OCR quality resulting from scans from aged and damaged pages or poor digitization (skewed or blurred images, ink bleed, or for some unknown cause.

To test possible classification gains from corrected OCR, we passed all 10,252 articles through the ‘overProof’ (Evershed and Fitch, 2014) OCR correction algorithm, and reran the classification process. OverProof combines an OCR error model with a contextual language model to identify and attempt to correct OCR errors. On a typical sample of digitized Australian newspapers from the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, overProof automatically corrects about 70% of OCR errors, but it can do little to correct extremely poorly OCRed text which contains few hints to be leveraged by statistical correction techniques. The language model component of overProof was trained on very large samples of ‘typical’ English text, and the language of poetry is significantly atypical, so only modest improvement was expected. After running overProof on the sample articles, 88.3% (an extra 477 or 4.4%) of articles were classified as poetry.

Table 1 below provides stable links to other examples of text in the newspapers database before correction and after correction by overProof that led to articles being successfully classified as poetry:

Processing the second set of 2,576 randomly selected (but not corrected by overProof) articles from the NLA corpus, 30 articles (1.16%) were classified as poems. Following manual inspection, 7 of these 30 are likely to be classified by an AustLit researcher as ‘containing poetry’. Hence the false-positive rate amongst the candidates automatically identified was 23/30, or 77%, but at least the number of articles needing to be reviewed by a human had been reduced from 2,576 in the original haystack to just 30 of which 23% are now likely to be ‘needles’. To further test effectiveness of the heuristics, a third much larger set of 12,912 articles (those with an id number ending in ‘7777’) was selected.
Article Before correct and after correct text (line boundaries not preserved in display)

View Large

Prior to OCR correction, 162 articles (1.25%) were classified as poetry, of which manual inspection confirmed 65 as poetry (0.50%). After automatic OCR correction by overProof, 237 articles (1.84%) were classified as poetry, of which manual inspection confirmed 81 as poetry (0.63%). That is, on this large sample, automatic correction increased candidates by 46% ((237 − 162)/162) and ‘true positives’ by 25% ((81 − 65)/65).

The ‘false positive’ rate amongst the 237 candidates identified as poems post-correction was high: 66%. That is, humans manually inspecting these candidates will classify only 1 in 3 as ‘really poems’. Another way of stating this result is that the ‘precision’ of the results was low: around 33%.

Our previous analysis of known poems suggested the classifier would find about 88.3% of poems present. Hence, as we found 81 poems from this sample of 12,912 articles, we could expect the actual number of articles in the sample that an AustLit bibliographer would classify as poetry as 81/0.883 Whilst our ‘recall’ (that is, the measure of actual instances of poetry identified) of poetry is quite high (over 85%), our precision (that is, the measure of identified instances of poetry which really are poetry) is low (between 20 and 40%).

Extrapolating these figures to the entire NLA Digitised Newspapers corpus of 160 million (and growing) articles, it would be expected that if they were automatically corrected, about 1.8%, or 2.9 million candidates would be identified, and about 0.63% of all articles, or about 1 million articles, would be identified by a human as poetry (Fig. 7).

img.alt: The extrapolation from outcomes of current project to the entire newspaper corpus

div.p: The extrapolation from outcomes of current project to the entire newspaper corpus

img.alt: The extrapolation from outcomes of current project to the entire newspaper corpus

div.p: The extrapolation from outcomes of current project to the entire newspaper corpus

As reported above, our heuristic classification of known poetry articles yielded about 88% ‘true positives’. If the sample of already-identified articles in AustLit is representative of yet-to-be-classified articles, then we would also expect this process to include about 88% of actual poetry articles in the candidate set of 3 million articles, but to miss about 12%, or, on these figures, about 140,000 articles. Based on the above analysis of misses, these would mostly be long articles containing relatively small sections of poetry.

Nearly 3 million articles form a very long queue for manual examination, so it would seem sensible to prioritize the examination to process the most likely candidates first, maximizing the number of poems found with limited human resources. The heuristic classification process produces a score which is effectively a measure of the confidence in the classification. From an examination of the 237 candidates generated from the corrected 3rd sample, the average score was 788 and the median score was 440. For the 156 false positives, the average score was 404 and the median score was 363. For the 81 true positives, the average score was 1,528 and the median score was 1,028.

If the 237 candidates were culled to those with scores of at least 900, the candidates would be reduced to 51 (22% of its original size), of which 45 (88%) would be ‘true positives’ and just 6 (12%) would be false positives.

Hence, assuming the candidate list itself is missing 12% of all articles a human would link as poetry, examining just the top candidates would find about 50% of articles containing poetry with little wasted effort. The remaining 38% amongst the lower-scoring candidates could be found with more human work (about 36 from the 186 candidates, or 19% true positives). The last 12% require manual inspection of newspaper pages.

Unfortunately, Underwood’s (2014) interim report was published after the experimental phase of our study, so we were not able to test the applicability of these features to the classification of poetry in newspapers. Many of his ‘structural’ metrics may not easily translate from pages in books to articles in newspapers. For example, newspaper articles are usually formatted into narrow columns, and the difference between words per line of poems and non-poems is not as marked in newspapers as in books. In addition, although the proportion of lines ending in punctuation is a promising measure, some of the most difficult article types to separate from poetry are those containing very short paragraphs of list-like material: sports and agricultural show results and descriptions of evening wear at receptions. Nevertheless, analysing line-ending punctuation (particularly commas or semicolons) may be a promising direction. We aim to return to a phase of further analysis at the end of 2016 and will take account of this work then.

Again, following the conclusion of our experimental phase, we have recently become aware of other projects undertaking interesting work in identifying poetry in periodicals or using image-based analysis. The Image Analysis for Archival Discovery (Aida) project, described by Lorang et al. (2015) uses a purely image processing approach to detect the left and right extent of lines of text in newspaper columns which is then processed by a trained neural network to identify blocks of poetry. In effect, Aida is using patterns of left indent and line length within a block of text in a very similar manner to our usage of left indent and line length variation. However, in our approach, the left indent is determined by the x offset of the first character in the first word on each line, and the line length is determined by the number of characters. Both our metrics are output from the OCR process. These are just two of the signals we use in classification, and our other signals (vocabulary, rhymes, presence of digits, tags, article type) would be expected to improve classification, which test results confirm. However, our results are not directly comparable as Aida is classifying image blocks, whereas we are classifying human-determined articles.

Given the success of our experiment and the capacity within the AustLit team to return to this work in late 2016, we will make a number of refinements to the approach. Our plans include working with academic colleagues who are specialists in nineteenth and early twentieth-century poetry to assist with expanding the number of signals our algorithm looks for, specifically enhancing the poetic vocabulary and identifying particularly poetic clause structures and phrases. We will also take account other advances in the field of poetry classification. Whilst techniques have been developed to perform automatic analysis of content known to be poetry (Green et al., 2010 and Tanasescu et al., 2016), they are not designed for classification of material into poetry/not-poetry. However, some approaches we would like to explore further are the use of a phrase classifier based on observations that some phrases (such as ‘thou art’ and ‘like a’) are over-represented in poetry compared to prose, and a pattern matcher to identify common patterns of similes (such as ‘as * as a’).

By early 2017, we will have developed a Graphical User Interface (GUI) work-flow tool within AustLit to allow efficient human processing of articles classified as poetry. Users will be able to reject a work (as not poetry), identify a work as already described by AustLit and attach a link to the newspaper article on an existing bibliographical record, assert that the work is a new manifestation of a recorded poem, or, identify as a new work to AustLit. We hope to engage volunteers and crowdsource some of the processing and derive feedback from human processing to reduce the false positives generated by the automatic classification process.

Following the conclusion of the poetry identification and metadata harvesting exercise, we will extend the approach to identify other creative writing, plus reviews and criticisms of literary works published in newspapers. And because AustLit’s primary focus is on works by Australian creators, a major challenge will be considering ways of identifying the creators of candidate articles within the work-flow GUI to assist in determining whether the creator is eligible. Cross-matching names heuristically identified from the article contents with creator records from AustLit, Trove, and aggregated library catalogues could be used to increase the probability of identifying authors that may not be Australian, while developing a method for interrogating New Zealand’s PapersPast corpus could assist with research into the trans-Tasman flow of literature between Australia and New Zealand. Additionally, this work suggests that other categories of content, characterized by a skewed, distinctive vocabulary, such as sports reports and fashion columns, would be amenable to automatic detection using an appropriately trained classifier, although many of the other cues on which we relied for poetry (rhyming lines, indents, and for sports reports, the presence of numerals) will be different, possibly absent or at least weaker. Some categories of ‘joke’ columns, for example, may also be detectable (perhaps by an over-representation of phrases such as ‘Knock knock…’, ‘What did the.’, and of question marks and exclamation marks). By developing and publishing this method, others may be able to successfully pursue that sort of work to reveal other cultural riches in historical newspapers.

Since Franco Moretti 2013 coined the phrase ‘distant reading’ in 2010, literary scholars have been searching for ways to analyse the massed artefacts of literary culture that digitization and database building allows. Ted Underwood is setting out ways that the HathiTrust can be used to undertake genre-level research on that corpus; others are doing similar work by exploring alternative techniques. The combination of techniques we are using will provide scholars with proven success in harvesting literary content from large newspaper corpora. We aim to enable literary scholars of Australian print culture, poetry, reading practices, and general literary history, to gain further insights into the place of poetry in the history of Australian newspapers and to open up a corpus of works to the varied interrogations scholars make, both computationally and on the level of individual or classes of works. An excellent outcome would be to facilitate work that removes the need to make assumptions or extrapolations based on partial data derived from what is humanly possible in traditional scholarly bibliography.
On My Lady in a New Bonnet.
By Dante Rossetti Rummins.
My lady hath a new and lovely bonnet,
And in it she doth look so passing sweet,
And, altogether, ‘tis so chaste and neat,
That I thereon am fain to write a sonnet.
Meseems, whenas my lady deigns to don it,
My heart no longer owneth me its master,
Bur ever beateth on from fast to faster,
Till gentle love hat penned a poem on it.
Pure white it is, with just one little rose,
That nestles next my lady’s shining hair,
As to be planted there were its great joy.
Ah me that I could share that dear repose–
And shelter me, for aye, in such loved lair–
Draught ‘twere to me of bliss without
alloy!
